ITEM 1. BUSINESS..summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - ITEM 1. BUSINESS section in bullet points:

• As of December 2024, Beyond Meat branded products were available at approximately 129,000 retail and foodservice outlets in more than 65 countries worldwide.

• All of Beyond Meat's U.S. retail products were certified Kosher and Halal as of December 2024.

• The primary components of animal-based meat (amino acids, lipids, carbohydrates, trace minerals, and water) are not exclusive to animals and are plentiful in plants.

• Beyond Meat creates its plant-based products using proprietary scientific processes that determine the architecture of the animal-based meat being replicated.

• All of Beyond Meat's products are made from simple ingredients without GMOs, no added hormones or antibiotics, and 0 mg of cholesterol per serving.

• The company has a state-of-the-art Innovation Center within its Campus Headquarters that brings together leading scientists from various disciplines to pursue its vision of perfectly building plant-based meat.

ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS. section in bullet points:

• Adverse economic and political conditions in the U.S. and international markets, including concerns about high inflation.
• Changes resulting from the change in the administration in the U.S., including greater restrictions on free trade through significant increases in tariffs on raw materials, ingredients, finished goods, and other products and supplies imported into the U.S.
• Potential inflationary price pressures due to higher interest rates.
• The company's history of losses and ability to achieve or sustain profitability.
• Reduced consumer confidence and changes in consumer spending and negative trends in consumer purchasing patterns.
• A further decrease in demand for plant-based meat category products.
• Identifying and executing cost-reduction initiatives, including workforce reductions and executive leadership changes.
• The timing and success of reducing operating expenses and achieving financial performance objectives.
• Accelerating activities to prioritize gross margin expansion and cash generation as part of the Global Operations Review.
• Changes to pricing architecture within certain channels.
• Cash-accretive inventory reduction initiatives.
• Further cost-reduction initiatives.

..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - . section in bullet points:

* In February 2024, BYND's board of directors delegated cybersecurity risk oversight to the Risk Committee.
* The Risk Committee oversees management's implementation of the Company's cybersecurity risk management program.
* The IT team, including the Director of IT, is responsible for assessing and managing material risks from cybersecurity threats.
* Members of the IT team have over 10+ years of experience in operations technology support across multiple industries.
* The IT team holds industry standard certifications related to System, Security, and Network Administration.
* The Risk Committee reports to the full board of directors regarding its activities.

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY..summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY. in bullet points:

• BYND has developed and implemented a cybersecurity risk management program to protect its data and systems.
• The program is designed based on the National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework (NIST CSF 2.0).
• The cybersecurity risk management program is integrated into the overall enterprise risk management program.
• A security team manages aspects of the program, including risk assessment processes, security controls, and response to cybersecurity incidents.
• BYND uses external service providers to assess or assist with certain aspects of its security controls, as needed.
• Cybersecurity awareness training is provided to employees, incident response personnel, and senior management.
• BYND has not identified material risks from known cybersecurity threats that have materially affected its operations or financial condition as of the filing date.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES section in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, Phase 1-A and Phase 1-B have approximately 142,000 rentable square feet.
• The company entered into an agreement to purchase a property in Enschede, Netherlands in 2022 for €6.3 million.
• A €0.9 million deposit was made during 2022 as part of the purchase agreement.
• The purchase agreement was terminated on February 2, 2024, and replaced with a lease agreement for approximately 114,000 square feet.

ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS..summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS. section in bullet points:

• BYND establishes an accrued liability for legal matters when loss contingencies are probable and estimable.
• The outcome of pending legal proceedings cannot be predicted with certainty, except for the settlement of certain actions.
• Management is unable to estimate the reasonable possible amount of loss or range of loss for material pending legal proceedings.
• It is not probable that the ultimate resolution of current matters will have a material adverse effect on BYND's business, financial condition, results of operations, or cash flows.
• The final results of any current or future proceeding cannot be predicted with certainty.

ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON E.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES in bullet points:

• Our common stock began trading on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol “BYND” on May 2, 2019.
• As of March 4, 2025, there were 149 holders of record of our common stock.
• The Company has not declared or paid any dividends, or authorized or made any distribution upon or with respect to any class or series of its capital stock.
• The total cumulative stockholder return on our common stock from December 31, 2019 through December 31, 2024 was relative to the performance of the NASDAQ Composite Index and the S&P Food and Beverage Select Industry Index.

. Risk Factors, and.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART II - Risk Factors section in bullet points:

• As of December 2024, Beyond Meat branded products were available at approximately 129,000 retail and foodservice outlets in more than 65 countries worldwide.

• Net revenues decreased to $326.5 million in 2024 from $343.4 million in 2023, representing a 4.9% decrease.

• The company has generated losses since inception, with net loss in 2024 and 2023 being $160.3 million and $338.1 million, respectively.

• Weak demand, driven by prolonged softness in the plant-based meat category and increased competition, resulted in declines in net revenues that were unable to be offset with commensurate cost reductions.

• The company's operating environment is affected by uncertainty related to macroeconomic issues, including ongoing weakened demand in the plant-based meat category, inflation, higher interest rates, current and proposed future tariffs, and potential recessionary concerns.

..summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - . section in bullet points:

• The Company's board of directors approved a plan to reduce the global non-production workforce by approximately 15% (or approximately 1,500 employees) and the total global workforce by approximately 2.5% (or approximately 25,000 employees).
• Estimated one-time cash charges for the 2025 Restructuring Initiative (RIF) in North America and EU: $1.0 million to $1.5 million.
• Estimated cash compensation operating expense savings from the 2025 RIF: $5.5 million to $6.5 million.
• Estimated non-cash savings from the 2025 RIF related to previously granted, unvested stock-based compensation: $1.0 million to $1.5 million.
• The Company plans to suspend its operational activities in China and reduce its workforce there by approximately 15% (or approximately 1,500 employees).
• Estimated one-time cash charges for the China Restructuring Initiative (RIF): $0.5 million to $1.0 million.
• Estimated cash compensation operating expense savings from the China RIF: $0.5 million to $1.0 million.
• Estimated one-time non-cash charges related to accelerated depreciation and impairment charges in China: $12.0 million to $17.0 million.

Note that these facts are based on the Company's estimates and may be subject to uncertainty and change.

ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DI.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK in bullet points:

• In 2021, BYND issued a total of $1.15 billion aggregate principal amount of Notes.
• The proceeds from the issuance of the Notes were approximately $1.0 billion, net of capped call transaction costs of $84.0 million and debt issuance costs totaling $23.6 million.
• Special interest on the Notes accrues at a rate per annum not exceeding 0.50% (subject to certain exceptions).
• The main ingredient in BYND's products is pea protein, which is sourced from Canada, France, and the United States, with substantially all sourced from Canada.
• Prices of pea protein and other ingredients are subject to factors beyond BYND's control, including adverse weather conditions, natural disasters, and changes in national and world economic conditions.

ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEM.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA. as bullet points:

• The financial statements of Beyond Meat, Inc. were audited by a public accounting firm registered with the PCAOB.
• The audit was conducted in accordance with the standards of the PCAOB and the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission.
• The auditor expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024.
• The auditor's responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company's financial statements based on their audits.
• The auditor conducted procedures to assess the risks of material misstatement and evaluate the accounting principles used by management.
• The critical audit matter communicated relates to the accounts or disclosures that are material to the financial statements, specifically inventory valuation.

ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES..summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES. in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, our management concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within specified time periods.
• Our internal control over financial reporting was designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and preparation for external purposes in accordance with GAAP.
• As of December 31, 2024, our management concluded that our internal control over financial reporting was effective based on the framework set forth in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013).
• The effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024 has been audited by Deloitte & Touche LLP.
• There were no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended December 31, 2024 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect our internal control over financial reporting.
• Our management does not expect that our disclosure controls and procedures or internal control over financial reporting will prevent all errors and all fraud.

ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION..summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION. section:

• On December 12, 2024, Chelsea Grayson adopted a trading plan intended to satisfy the affirmative defense of Rule 10b5-1(c) of the Exchange Act, covering up to 20,285 shares of BYND common stock.
• On December 13, 2024, Ethan Brown, president and CEO, adopted a trading plan intended to satisfy the affirmative defense of Rule 10b5-1(c), covering up to 34,880 shares of BYND common stock.

ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS A.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE. in bullet points:

• The Proxy Statement will be filed with the SEC within 120 days of the fiscal year ended December 31, 2024.
• Our board of directors has adopted a code of business conduct and ethics that applies to all employees, officers, and directors.
• The full text of our code of business conduct and ethics is posted on our website at https://investors.beyondmeat.com/investor-relations.
• Our board of directors has adopted an insider trading policy governing the purchase, sale, and/or other dispositions of our securities by directors, officers, and employees.

ITEM 15. EXHIBIT AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART IV - ITEM 15. EXHIBIT AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULES in bullet points:

• The Index to Financial Statements is located in Item 8 of the report.
• All financial statement schedules have been omitted due to not being required under related instructions or being non-applicable.
• The information required for financial statement schedules is already included in the financial statements or notes to those financial statements.
• Certain documents are filed herewith (not specified) and incorporated by reference into the report.

Here are the key facts extracted from PART IV - ITEM 16. FORM 10-K SUMMARY. section as bullet points:
